variant.question: If ice is present on the leading edge of the wings, it may increase the landing distance due to a higher V~AT~ by as much as:
While performing a take-off under icing conditions, the pilot rotates the aircraft at the correct speed and rate, but notices that the aircraft does NOT lift off as expected. What could be the cause?

options.text: Ice can distort the flow of air over the wing, increasing the angle of attack for maximum lift and significantly increasing drag.
The rotation speed is too fast, significantly increasing drag and preventing the aircraft to lift off.
The rotation rate is too fast, increasing the critical angle of attack and preventing the aircraft to lift off.
The angle of attack during rotation exceeds the lower, icing-induced angle of attack, preventing the aircraft from becoming airborne.

variant.question: If you are landing on a warm summerâ€™s day, the increased temperature of the runway will:

options.text: Add to the effects of the ground effect
Subtract from the effects of the ground effect
Ground effect cannot exist in hot conditions
Not add to the ground effect

variant.question: How are stalling speed, stalling angle of attack  and control changed by aircraft icing?

options.text: Stall speed increases, stalling angle of attack decreases, and control decreases.
Stalling speed increases, stalling angle of attack increases, and control increases.
Stalling speed decreases, stalling angle of attack decreases, and control decreases.
Stalling speed increases, stalling angle of attack decreases, and control increases.

variant.question: What locations are the most susceptible to ice build-up during flight?

options.text: Parts of the aircraft that have a small radius, bend sharply, and hence have a higher curvature, such as narrow leading edges of the wings and tail, probes and antennas.
The radome, all the leading edges, upper wing surfaces, and the fuselage.
The windscreens and other cockpit windows.
Parts of the aircraft that have a large radius, and hence are gently curving, with a lower curvature, such as leading edge of a thick wing, the radome, and the fuselage.

variant.question: While flying under icing conditions, the largest ice build-up will occur, principally, on:

options.text: the frontal areas of the aeroplane.
the upper and lower surfaces on the rear of the wing.
the pitot and static probes only.
the upper and lower rudder surfaces.

variant.question: While flying under icing conditions, the largest ice build-up will occur, principally, on:

options.text: the frontal areas of the aircraft.
the upper and lower surfaces on the rear of the wing.
the upper and lower rudder surfaces.
the pitot and static probes only.

variant.question: Its a cold day, the pilot did not do de-ice nor anti-ice the aircraft. How will ice accretion affect the aircraft performance?

options.text: The drag will increase due to contamination and C~LMAX~ will reduce.
The drag will increase, it is fine as long the aircraft can become airborne.
Stall speed increases, the drag decreases.
The drag will increase due to contamination, but the aircraft will take off normally.

variant.question: An aeroplane without icing protection ventures into atmospheric conditions where icing will occur. What effect will this have on the aeroplane?

options.text: Stall speed will increase, and both the critical angle of attack and controllability will decrease.
Stall speed, the critical angle of attack and controllability will all increase.
Stall speed will decrease, and both the critical angle of attack and controllability will increase.
Stall speed will remain unchanged, and the critical angle of attack and controllability will decrease.

variant.question: What is going to happen to the angle of attack, controllability and stall speed if an airplane encounters icing during flight?

options.text: Angle of attack and controllability are going to decrease, stall speed is going to increase.
Angle of attack and controllability are going to increase, stall speed is going to decrease.
Angle of attack, controllability and stall speed are going to increase.
Angle of attack, controllability and stall speed are going to decrease.

variant.question: Following de-icing on a foggy morning, you are in the takeoff roll and notice that you need more thrust than expected. What could be a cause of this?

options.text: Ice build-up remaining on the fuselage means you are heavier than expected.
Increased fuel density due to low temperatures.
A higher angle of attack due to the higher speed in icing conditions.
Reduced air density due to low temperatures.

variant.question: The effect of tailplane icing can be to:

options.text:
Reduce longitudinal stability and decrease elevator
authority

Increase longitudinal stability and elevator
authority

Increase longitudinal stability and reduce elevator
authority

Reduce longitudinal stability and increase elevator
authority

variant.question: What type of drag is increased when an aerofoil is contaminated by dust and other particles?

options.text: Parasite drag
Wave drag
Induced drag
Material drag

variant.question: When landing an aircraft at an airfield during a hot day, the increased temperature of the runway will:

options.text: Add to the effects of Ground Effect.
Require a lower flap setting.
Subtract from the effects of Ground Effect.
Have no effect.

variant.question: Your aircraft is de-iced in a section of an aerodrome with poor lighting. After takeoff you realise your climb gradient is lower than expected. What is the cause?

options.text: The weight of the remaining ice on the aircraft structure
Lower thrust output due to the cold conditions
The increased weight of the fuel due to the cold temperatures and increased density
The increased air density impeding the aircraft's flight path

variant.question: An aircraft is configured for take-off and about to take-off. If the slats on the right wing remained retracted, what are the possible consequences?

options.text: The right wing can stall after rotation.
The left wing can stall after rotation.
The right wing can stall when trailing edge flap are retracted.
The left wing can stall when trailing edge flap are retracted.

variant.question: It is a cold day with visible moisture. You do not de-ice and there is no anti-icing available. How will this affect the aircraft performance?

options.text: Drag will increase due to contamination and CLMAX will reduce
Drag will increase due to contamination, but the aircraft will take off normally
Drag will increase due to contamination, it is fine as long as the aircraft can become airborne
Stall speed will increase, drag will decrease

variant.question: An aircraft is de-iced on the ground in bad lighting conditions. After take-off, the crew is forced to apply higher than normal thrust to achieve the desired rate of climb. This is most likely due to...

options.text: airframe contamination resulting in increased weight.
high speed being maintained in order to avoid ice formation.
the low prevailing OAT, resulting in a higher fuel density.
the low prevailing OAT, resulting in less dense air.

variant.question: An aircraft is performing a take-off when it encounters windshear. What action should be taken?

options.text: Pitch up to a value close to the stall warning.
Speed control is more important than a pitch input.
Wait to apply full power until being stabilised in the climb.
Pitch up to a value just above stall warning alarm.

variant.question: When ice accretion builds up on the leading edge of the tailplane, the effect could be:

options.text: Uncontrollable pitch-down, which will be made worse by upwards elevator deflection, and deployment of trailing edge flaps.
Uncontrollable pitch down, which will be made worse by downwards elevator deflection and retraction of trailing edge flaps
Uncontrollable pitch-up, which will be made worse by downwards elevator deflection and deployment of trailing edge flaps
Uncontrollable pitch-down, which will be made worse by upwards elevator deflection and retraction of trailing edge flaps

variant.question: Unless the Aircraft Manual permits otherwise, before take-off the regulations require:

options.text: All aircraft surfaces to be clear of ice and snow
The upper surface of the wing to be clear of ice and snow
The upper surface of the wing and empennage to be clear of ice and snow
All aircraft surfaces to be clear of ice and snow except that hoar frost is allowed

variant.question:
What is the effect of icing or other airframe contaminants on the value of CLMAX, stall speed, and critical angle of attack? 
 The CLMAX...

options.text: decreases, stall speed increases, and critical angle of attack decreases.
remains unchanged, stall speed increases, and critical angle of attack decreases.
increases, stall speed decreases, and critical angle of attack increases.
increases, stall speed increases, and critical angle of attack decreases.

variant.question:
What words must be used to complete the statement below? 
A wing, contaminated with ice, will typically stall at __
1) Angle Of Attack (AOA) and at __
2) airspeed, with small amounts of ice having already an effect, whereby the effect __
3) if the ice is rough.

options.text: 1. a lower 2. a higher 3. is greater
1. a higher 2. a higher 3. is greater
1. a higher 2. a lower 3. is greater
1. a lower 2. a lower 3. is greater
